I believe that persons having a degree means nothing more than they spent more time and money in or on school .
I also think a degree obtained today does not carry the weight of one obtained 30 years ago .
I also think a degree obtained today does not carry the weight of one obtained 30 years ago .
Back in the good old days , sourcing information in the pursuit of a degree took REAL work , whereas today everything is but a few keystrokes away , thanks to the Internet .
I posit , though , that in Jamaica , that notion has been tossed out the window .
A degree here now acts as a status symbol , something that entitles its holder to look at and treat those without one as inferior .

No , I am not envious of people who have degrees .
In fact , based on the Jamaican experience , it would appear that people generally are worse off for having them .

I was at one time under the impression that being in possession of a degree meant that having undergone special training , one had attained a level in thinking that was above that of the ordinary person .

I was at one time under the impression that being in possession of a degree meant that having undergone special training , one had attained a level in thinking that was above that of the ordinary person .
Listening to and seeing some of the people who have degrees in action , though , I realise how far off the mark I truly was .

To illustrate my point , I ask readers to impartially answer one question : Given a choice between Kingsley ' Ragashanti ' Stewart and Wilmot ' Motty ' Perkins , who would you prefer your child to be like when they grow up ?
